You need to activate your body first, from slow stretching work to a bit active workout like running at home. I recommend you to do Taiji, slow movement in a small space, let your energy start to flow through your whole body. You can do 10-15 minutes several times through the day when you feel your body is stiff and your brain starts to slow down. Close your eyes for 5 minutes between the tasks, slow down your breathing, let go everything, stay calm and still. Turn off your phone after your office hour, do something like cooking, listening to the music, singing, dancing, gardening, any hobby you have.  Eat a light dinner, play light music, read a book, not on electronic device. After that, write a short self-reflection journal about the day, or any issue in your mind, just empty it, go to sleep no later than 10pm, then get up at 6am.

Responsegivenbyheuser.answer: I'm not sure that the pandemic has changed the fundamentals of leadership. Lewin kicked it all off in the '30s with his designation of autocratcratic and laissez-faire leaders. Bass' concept of the transformational leader may originate in the 1970's but still feels every bit as relevant. His 4 i's, idealized influence, inspirational motivation, intellectual stimulation and individual consideration are a fantastic framework for any leader. Then there is Blanchard and Hersey's Situational Leadership, a practical model for leading individuals. In my personal experience the best leaders are self-aware, authentic and humble. They hold themselves accountable and they face up to issues and conflict. These are capabilities that transcend the moment and so are as importnat now as they ever were.

users.question: Does anyone experience situations where subordinates who share a religious identity with you wrongly assume that you will share all of the same values and treat them exceptionally? I have had multiple employees approach me with inappropriate comments about co-workers because they believe I will automatically side with them. I am never sure how to respond aside from politely telling them that it is none of their business. I was hoping someone might have advice on how to prevent/address these situations.

Responsegivenbyheuser.question: 6229eedd8553e7ab6730c46f
Responsegivenbyheuser.answer: If I had an employee exhibiting those behaviors, I would let them know that you noticed they seem off and ask if there is something with their job that you can help improve.  They may open up about a work related issue that you can assist with or there may be something in their personal life. If the latter is the case, then you can reiterate that you offered the days off to promote work/life balance if indeed there is something they need to take care of. Also, does your company offer some sort of employee assistance program (somewhere they can call for counseling or advice)? Some people just need to know their boss cares about their wellbeing and that is enough to help them out of a funk. On the other hand, a few people are just like that and there is nothing you can do for them besides provide the tools they need to be successful in their job. If they choose not to use those tools then that is their choice and their performance or conduct deficiencies should be dealt with accordingly. If that person's sour attitude is impacting the morale and productivity of others then a more serious personnel action may be in order.

Responsegivenbyheuser.question: 6229eeed8553e7ab6730c563

As a leader you need breaks to step away from your work, breaks that allow you to get substantial rest and allow your mind to wonder elsewhere. Through such break, your company, or the individuals you are leading will benefit in the long run. Productivity and efficiency can also be improved by allowing yourself to take a break and prioritize your well-being.

However, if you are addressing this with staff under you, the situation has two crucial prongs. If are part of an environment in which it is not okay to make a mistake, then this is a difficult situation. But it's an opportunity for you to turn the culture around. If you are running a growth-oriented team, this is a good time for you to lead by example, be outright about your mistake, and be humble about it. This can be an excellent opportunity for you to build rapport with your team members.

Responsegivenbyheuser.answer: I would suggest two things. Firstly, develop a strategy map that links tangible goals/objectives to the elements (and only the elements) that are necessary to complete them. Assign one person as responsible for that area and make them honestly show the status as red/orange/green on the map. That gives you your strategic resource allocation and makes it easy to stop pet projects that are wasting time and money. Secondly, practice a meeting technique called qualified consensus - everyone gets their say and feels heard, but you as the leader remain in control. Responsegivenbyheuser.answer: My first thought is a S.W.O.T (Strengths, Weakness,  Opportunities and Threats) evaluation followed by a team member eval. Doing so will answer the quesitons of why leadership is having a hard time; are they Leading or Managing? Leaders work WITH teams, demonstrating best practices, empowering members to be innovative, to make mistakes without fear of being "thrown under the bus" for a mistake; communicating effectively with the team which means, no egos in the room. Will this elleviate all heistitancy, perhaps not. However, there is a better chance that a team will willing following a respected and trusted leader with a higher buy-in. If those at the top are managing, I have found elevated instances of resistance and push-back. I firmly believe that resources (and people are NOT resources), time, money etc., are managed; team members are lead. If this first hurdle is effectively addressed, the rest will fall into place.

Responsegivenbyheuser.question: 6229eef48553e7ab6730c5da
Responsegivenbyheuser.answer: Instincts are shortcuts that we make in decision making. They are vital for us to cope with everyday life. We develop good instincts when we encounter the same situation and the same outcome again and again. Most of us drive mainly on instinct. We don't think about which foot to use to push the brake or how many degrees to turn the wheel. This allows us to invest more of our conscious thought in other tasks such as looking out for other drvers, or following directions on our satnav. But it also stops us forom questioning our decisions. In the US, when I pull up to a red light, I assume it is okay to turn right, and I often do without much thought. That wouldn't go down well in the UK, where other drivers and pedestrians will be assuming that I will stop. When we apply these mental shortcuts to activities such as hiring, we also make decisions without challenging our assumptions, and that is the root of bias. The answer is to use data to challenge decisions. There is an article about this on HBR, https://online.hbs.edu/blog/post/data-driven-decision-making. My business is providing data to support hiring decisions. So connect with me if you are interested and we can discuss further.

Responsegivenbyheuser.question: 6229eef48553e7ab6730c5da

Responsegivenbyheuser.question: 6229eef48553e7ab6730c5da
Responsegivenbyheuser.answer: Absolutely!  Any hiring manager can fall victim to confirmation bias. Ways to check for bias include using a panel interview of trusted people as part of the hiring process. Also, the use of objective pre-hire assessments focused on the most critical knowledge, skills, and abilities can uncover bias.

Responsegivenbyheuser.question: 6229eeeb8553e7ab6730c538
Responsegivenbyheuser.answer: It's important to write to the future, not the past. Your resumé is a marketing document, and your current career goals should always determine which parts of your story to highlight and which to minimize. With that, you want to make sure you're showcasing “wow factor”, just a quick hit of information that highlights your achievements and that shows up prominently throughout your resumé. Also as cliché as it may sound, spicing up the design on your resumé can help as well. Cautiously of course, but color, shading, boxes, charts, tables, images and icons can be valuable additions to your resumé, helping to make it stand out. Just make sure your design matches industry norms for your field.

It might be a good idea to discuss the feedback in detail of how this candidate ranked against the other, their shortfalls, how they can improve and discuss how serious you are about helping them achieve their goal. A timeline of how you envision them progressing to the role they wanted should they wish to stay with your company. This shows that you not only used a set criteria that had nothing to do with race, to make the promotion decision, but you are activiely interested in mentoring the employee to reach their potential and their goal.
